keywords.definition: the nonliving factors in an environment, such as temperature, light, water, and nutrients.
To take in or soak up.
Rain that has been made acidic by certain pollutants in the air.
The process of changing to an environment; developing physical and behavioral characteristics that allow organisms to survive and have offspring.
When unwanted chemicals, gasses, and particles enter the air and the atmosphere, causing harm to animals and damaging the natural cycles of the Earth.
Large growths of algae caused by increased amounts of phosphorus or nitrogen.
Height above a certain level and especially above sea level.
Living or growing in water.
The blanket of gases that surround the Earth.
Organisms that produce their own food.
Able to be broken down by the action of living organisms such as bacteria.
The variety of plant and animal life in a habitat.
A large region of Earth that has a certain climate and certain types of living things.
the living parts of an environment, such as plants and animals.
A dense layer of leaf-covering in a forest that blocks the sun from the forest floor.
An animal that eats another animal.
The green coloring matter found mainly in the chloroplasts of plants that absorbs energy from sunlight to produce carbohydrates from carbon dioxide and water during photosynthesis.
Organelles that make food for the plant cell and where photosynthesis takes place.
Nutrients that do not leave or enter planet Earth.
All of the different populations living in the same place.
To try to outdo another organism for food, sunlight, water, space, etc.
The strength of a solution, or how much of a substance is mixed with another substance.
Any animal that eats plants or eats other plant-eating animals.
A small animal that lives in warm water and attaches itself to rocks, with some types building a hard skeleton
Living organisms that need warm, shallow water to form.
Any of the fungi or bacteria that break down dead plants and animals into useful things like minerals and rich soil.
The process of breaking down dead animals, plants, and waste into nutrients.
Any of the fungi or bacteria that break down dead plants and animals into useful things like minerals and rich soil.
The clearing, or cutting down, of forests.
The organic processes by which food is converted into substances that can be absorbed into the body.
The study of interactions between living and non-living things.
All the living and non-living things in an environment, including their interactions with each other.
A pure substance that is made from a single type of atom.
Height especially above sea level.
The ability to do work. It exists in various forms, such as thermal or electrical, and it can be converted from one form to another.
When rocks and sediments are picked up and moved to another place by ice, water, wind, or gravity.
A process in which a body of water receives a large bounty of nutrients, especially phosphates. These chemicals can enter the ecosystem naturally or through pollution.
Trees that stay green all year and form a canopy.
Any substance such as manure or a mixture of nitrates used to make soil more fertile, or productive.
The path of the energy in food from one organism to another.
Water that is not salty.
A large area of thick ice that remains frozen from one year to the next.
A type of sugar. Hydrogen combines with carbon dioxide to make glucose. Starch is made of many glucose particles joined together.
Water that is located beneath the surface of the ground.
The place where a plant or animal naturally lives and grows.
An animal that eats plants, algae, and other producers.
An organism that eats another organism to get energy.
A solution with a low pH, such as lemon juice.
The amount of water vapor in the air.
An inability to exist or survive without each other.
An animal that does not have a backbone or skeleton inside of its body.
The deterioration, or destruction, of the Earth’s land surfaces.
A colorless, odorless gaseous chemical element that makes up 78% of the atmosphere and forms a part of all living tissues.
Animals that sleep during the day and are awake during the night.
A substance found in food that helps living things grow, develop, and function properly
A continuous cycle in which nutrients on earth are naturally recycled
A larva of an insect with incomplete metamorphosis.
An animal that eats both plants and animals.
Material that is biodegradable and comes from a plant or an animal.
Any living thing that can carry out its life on its own.
A chemical used to kill pests, such as rodents or insects.
A chemical element that glows in the dark and in moist air.

A type of smog produced when ultraviolet light from the sun reacts with nitrogen oxides in the atmosphere. It is visible as a brown haze and most common during the morning and afternoon, especially in highly populated, warm cities.
The process of using energy in sunlight to make food from water and carbon dioxide.
Particles, chemicals, or substances that make water contaminated.
A group of the same kind of organisms that live together.
An animal that hunts other animals for food.
An animal that is hunted and killed by another animal for food.
An organism that makes its own food.
Organisms that eat plants for energy.
Those gases or particles that are pumped into the air to make it unclean. They include carbon monoxide from automobile exhausts and sulfur dioxide from the combustion of coal.
Organisms that eat Tertiary Consumers.
Using things that have already been used before.
An area of land that has common features or characteristics.
The process in which the chemical bonds of energy-rich molecules, such as glucose, are converted into energy usable for life processes.
Precipitation that flows across the land’s surface or falls into rivers and streams.
Water that is salty.
A tropical grassland with some trees and shrubs.
An animal that feeds on dead or decaying material.
Organisms that eat primary consumers or other animals.
When pollutants in the air mix up in a chemical reaction, they form a dangerous chemical. Photochemical smog is an example of this and is a secondary pollutant.
The loose upper layer of the Earth’s surface where plants grow.
Unwanted solid materials such as garbage, paper, plastics, and metals.
Smallest group of classification.
A biome far from the equator with much rainfall and a wide variety of life.
Living or growing on land.
Organisms that eat Secondary Consumers.
The animal at the top of a food chain that has no natural enemies.
The rich upper layer of soil in which plants have most of their roots.
Containing, being, or caused by poisonous or dangerous material.
Energy level.
A hot biome near the equator with much rainfall and a wide variety of life.
The contamination of water bodies, such as lakes, rivers, or oceans, very often by human activities.
The daily state of the atmosphere, or air, in any given place.
